Chree Centuries of Busiress

Trade routes of the world—by water, by
land and by air—are arteries carrying a con-
tinual flow of business through the “‘heart”
which is Baltimore. More than fifty steam-
ship lines move twenty million tons of cargo
annually: mainline railroads carry still other
millions of tons; additional millions of tons
flow in all directions by highway transport:
even the air is made to carry a vast commerce
to and from Baltimore . . . a commerce parti-
cipated in by some two thousand manufac-
turing plants, extensive wholesale and retail
establishments . . . in short, BIG BUSINESS
for Baltimore.

Business was here before Baltimore—and
Baltimore has grown mighty through de-
votion to business. A century before the
establishment in 1729 of a custom-house,
occasion for the founding of Baltimore, one
Capt. Henry Fleet engaged in the fur trade
in this area. Later, the dominant business
was in tobacco. As crop, merchandise, cur-
rency—tobacco was the life of trade. Agricul-

ture, industry, commerce and finance all met

and mingled in tobacco. Valued at a penny
a pound, it was legal tender for taxes or
debts; currency for making any purchase. If
that seems a primitive economy, listen to
this:

““In 1666 Nathaniel Utie was one of the
commissioners appointed to effect an agree-
ment between Virginia, North Carolina, and
Maryland to suspend the planting of tobacco
for a year, so as to enhance its value!”

There were giants in those days. Men had
to be. Surrounded by a wilderness, with
slow transportation and communications,
water wheels their
only power—yet,
men founded manu-
facturing and milling

businesses, entered



into shipping which circled the world, bring-
ing its wealth here to their warehouses.
They fought for and established our nation

~and served it generously and still had time for

gracious, leisurely living! No wonder, with
such a tradition, Baltimore is a great indus-

THE

Established in 1922, the chosen name, Oriole, and
the same management, have continued to be asso-
ciated with and a part of Baltimore. Starting in one
location—at 32 S. Calvert St., by serving Baltimoreans
well, three large establishments are now required.
We omit the astronomical figures that would be re-
quired to record how many meals, how many oysters,
how many pats of butter, lumps of sugar, cups of
coffee, etc., we have served. Rather, let us merely
remind you that the great volume of business of the
Orioles is but the result of comsistently serving good
food, modsrately priced, in clean, inviting surroundings.

3 ORIOLE
CAFETERIAS

Oriole Cafeteria Number
One, since 1924 at 22 Light
Street, supplanted by the
new Oriole at 17 East Balti-
more Street, serves the finan-
cial and business districts.

Number Two, at 306 North
Howard Street, is convenient
to the Lexington-Howard
retail shopping district. Es-
Many
* early shoppers breakfast here

while awaiting the opening
of nearby stores.

The third Oriole Cafeteria,
established at 11 East North
Avenue, is in the heart of
the uptown business and
shopping center where, since
1933, it has served this busy

Community. North Avenue near Charles
